title: Geth stops its sync for hours
body:
#### System information

Geth version:
```
Geth
Version: 1.7.3-stable
Git Commit: 4bb3c89d44e372e6a9ab85a8be0c9345265c763a
Architecture: amd64
Protocol Versions: [63 62]
Network Id: 1
Go Version: go1.7
Operating System: linux
GOPATH=
GOROOT=/usr/local/go
```
OS & Version: `Ubuntu 16.04.3 LTS`


#### Expected behaviour

geth should remain in sync with the network.

#### Actual behaviour

My geth instance gets randomly stuck at certain blocks for hours and then randomly starts sync'ing again.

This is causing major problems with transaction propagation in the node.

At the time of writing geth hasn't restarted in over 8 days but we started seeing this problem less than 24 hours ago.

I have 6 hours worth of logs in `debug.verbosity(4)` where the node is alive and outputting stuff but not sync'ing. Since yesterday my node constantly gets in this state.

```
2018-01-06 06:35:19.021313500 INFO [01-06|06:35:19] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1  txs=226  mgas=7.999  elapsed=1.047s    mgasps=7.636   number=4862139 hash=f5fbc1…6ba255
.... Many hours pass of DEBUG output I will attach and then:
2018-01-06 15:54:51.202876500 INFO [01-06|15:54:51] Imported new chain segment               blocks=2  txs=1269 mgas=15.991 elapsed=4.896s    mgasps=3.266   number=4862140 hash=d6e0aa…938a41 ignore
d=3
```

When it's in this state I have run `net.peerCount` to see if it's a peering issue, but the node seems to consistently have 25 peers (the default max).

Also, this node is sitting in a pretty big CPU/RAM machine and neither CPU nor RAM seem to be the issue. It's all pretty quiet in that box (can provide graphs/specs if requested)

#### Steps to reproduce the behavior

Unfortunately this is happening pretty randomly

[ether.log](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/files/1609046/ether.log)
Attaching CPU/load/RAM/Network traffic info over the last 2 weeks for completeness.
Thanks for the info! When it's in this state, behind but not obviously syncing, could you get a stack trace via the debug rpc api? Then we could easily see what the threads are doing...
I think it's debug_stacks
Really useful log btw, contain a lot of interesting data. We're analysing it

Thanks @holiman - I'm glad the log is helpful.

I don't have the `debug` module enabled over HTTP so I will call `debug.stacks()` on the console and attach the output.
i have same proble... did you get solution ? @vogelito
I too have similar problem with geth VERSION: 1.7.3-stable-4bb3c89d.

same here - can't get synced since last week - Geth/v1.7.3-stable/windows-amd64/go1.9.2. Node is running 24/7 and most of time (like 90% or more) about 50 blocks behind the chain. Occasionally, it gets synced but then stucks again.

Please take a stack dump for the geth team.

My solution was to wait and be patient.

I haven’t seen geth get stuck again, but I had to restart my geth to resolve the gas miscalculation problem.

Hi, this is happening right now. Attaching output of `debug.stacks()`

let me know if you want anything else
[2018.01.08_debug_stacks.log](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/files/1612469/2018.01.08_debug_stacks.log)

My parity node is on block 4875619. Our geth node is on 4875410

Currently in my instance:
```
ether-mainnet:/home/ubuntu# cat /opt/ethereum-node/log/main/current | tai64nlocal | grep Imported | tail -1
2018-01-08 16:49:31.606171500 INFO [01-08|16:49:31] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=211  mgas=7.995  elapsed=575.833ms mgasps=13.885  number=4875410 hash=5917be…2d459c
ether-mainnet:/home/ubuntu# date
Mon Jan  8 17:46:47 UTC 2018
```

So roughly an hour without any blocks.

And I start geth with:
```
/home/ubuntu/geth/current/geth --rpc --rpcapi "debug,personal,eth,web3" --targetgaslimit 1000000 --cache 1024 --lightserv 20 --gpopercentile 30
```
My node is now caught up. However, for some reason it's broadcasting the transactions in the `eth.pendingTransactions` queue at a very slow rate of about 1 tx/block

for me it was more or less resolved by doubling cache size, node managed to get synced and stays in sync most of time. Sometimes it stuck for awhile with "dropping peer err=timeout" or "err=retrieved hash chain is invalid" (but those I consider to be peer issues or isn't it?) then it manage to get synced pretty quickly.
Memory and disk consumption is above 80% most of the time.
Thanks @alicenew - what's your cache size set to now?
Geth just hung for about 5 minutes - here is the debug.stacks() output: [geth.log](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/files/1618749/geth.log)

Hi,

This is becoming a pretty big issue for us. Is there any more info we can provide to help you debug? We would really appreciate your help with it.

Once the node gets into this mode it sort of refuses to broadcast transactions and I have to rebroadcast them all with a script.
It's on my priority list hopefully for tomorrow. Been sick for the entire week. Those stacks should help a lot
Thank you so much @holiman - really appreciate it and hope you get better soon.

I am adding one more log - currently stuck at block 4892652
[geth1.log](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/files/1624215/geth1.log)

Holiman Kenobi, you're our only hope!

Running like this: geth --maxpeers 60 --lightserv 50 --lightpeers 35 --cache 2048
Sort of same problem here; tried to mitigate it in several ways, but IMHO it's mostly a net problem...
My question though: why does it download some latest blocks twice?
Look here for block number=489316: downloaded twice with different hashes. Is this normal behavior?
Looking forward to knowing if this behavior of randomly stalling the sync can be eliminated some how.
Thanks all!

Jan 12 02:33:32 gethservice[14605]: INFO [01-12|02:33:32] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=218  mgas=7.988  elapsed=1.568s          mgasps=5.093  number=4893614 hash=0a4fbf…6031d8
Jan 12 02:34:40  gethservice[14605]: INFO [01-12|02:34:40] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=305  mgas=7.990  elapsed=2.442s          mgasps=3.271  number=4893615 hash=64a176…02162e
Jan 12 02:34:55  gethservice[14605]: INFO [01-12|02:34:55] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=317  mgas=7.977  elapsed=2.846s          mgasps=2.802  number=4893616 hash=005ae6…afe8bd
Jan 12 02:35:04  gethservice[14605]: INFO [01-12|02:35:04] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=354  mgas=7.987  elapsed=2.888s          mgasps=2.765  number=4893617 hash=410ed9…8415e0
Jan 12 02:35:29  gethservice[14605]: INFO [01-12|02:35:29] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=324  mgas=7.912  elapsed=2.572s          mgasps=3.075  number=4893616 hash=ea7e1d…33b68f
Jan 12 02:35:36  gethservice[14605]: INFO [01-12|02:35:36] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=297  mgas=7.988  elapsed=2.396s          mgasps=3.334  number=4893618 hash=f853e2…e95206
Jan 12 02:35:48  gethservice[14605]: INFO [01-12|02:35:48] Imported new chain segment               blocks=1 txs=352  mgas=7.992  elapsed=3.180s          mgasps=2.513  number=4893619 hash=64bc90…30448b
I've done a first analysis of (some of ) the raw data, but not yet looked into possible causes: https://gist.github.com/holiman/5ec5d518c0ebe602872e37bd5775f0ef
As an experiment, could you try _not_ running `--lightserv`, and see if that makes any difference?
This sounds very much like the issue I reported in https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/issues/15689 (i.e. sometimes I have only light peers and cannot download any blocks).
Oh indeed! Setting lightpeers is at the cost of full peers. But @vogelito is not setting that particular flag, though...(?)
Iirc, it defaults to 20, so running geth like @vogelito does effectively halves the allowed number of full peers
@holiman yes, the default `--lightpeers` value is 20 (see [here](https://github.com/ethereum/go-ethereum/blob/master/cmd/utils/flags.go#L179-L183)).

Happy to remove the `lightserve` option. Just let me know if that’s what you want me to do.

@axelay are you running geth with that flag on?
No we are not
